bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 16, 1879

div1.p: Reed corrects Emilie Lawrence Reed's misapprehension about the date of his reassignment. He expects to return east by June 30.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 16, 1879
div1.p:
We waited long
and patiently, on Sunday last, for the arrival
of the mail, but all our waiting was in vain.
Of course, old mantee got quite out of humor
at not receiving a letter from darling little
lovie, especially as he had waited all day
for it, just like a little man. And as it turned
out, we had to endure the privation of
news till Monday evening at sunset-(yesterday)
This is written on Tuesday morning, & a beau-
tiful, bright, warm morning it is- But I've
got just the least touch of a headache, due
to the fact that I did not sleep well last
night. And would precious wifie like to
know why my sleep was disturbed and broken?
Doesn't she already surmise? Ah! wifie
dear, what had got into that sweet, little
head of yours, when you wrote those two
last letters, dated 24 & 29 November? Was
my pretty wifie suffering from “acidity
of the stomach” when she wrote them?
What did old ugly mantee write in
yourhis last letter that should have set
that little brain to thinking so wildly &
that pretty tongue to wagging at such a
rate? Who told you, precious wifie, that
I wasn't coming East till next Fall? I cer-
-tainly could not have written such a
thing in any of my letters- If I remember
correctly, you asked me if I could tell my
pretty wifie about what time I would be
ordered out of Arizona, and I, like a “feetning”
little mantee, sat down and pumbled my head
for half an hour or so, & gave in writing the
only ideas that I could deduce- I said, lovie,
dear, (if I can recall my former statements
to memory,) that, if my tour was reckoned from
the date of my departure from the East, then
I would be relieved about May 1st- But
if it was reckoned from the date of my
assignment to duty in Arizona, then my tour
would expire June 21st- And then I went
on to tell my darling (and I didn't think that
she would pounce upon this one date as
a settled thing,) that if I was required to serve
out my leaves, then I would not be relieved
till Octr 1st. Now, darling Nemps, how you
have found out that I will not be or-
-dered out till Octr 1st, I really don't
know- Why, my little wifie, should have
skipped May and June & pitched upon Octr
so savagely, I really don't know, unless it
be that she wants to see her ugly old mantee
so badly and is determined to look on the dark
side of the picture! Of course, lovie, dear, you
well know, that mantee is not mad with
you or at all inclined to be angry or
displeased, but he can't keep from feel-
ing worried and anxious about his loving
little wifie, when he reads such heart-
-rending letters as your last two were-
When he thinks that his darling wifie is
happy and cheerful & enjoying her stay East,
then he too, feels bright & gay; but when
he reads what that which tells him that his poor
little darling's very heart-strings are break-
-ing and her life filled with gloom, why
then his thoughts must partake of the melan-
-cholic, too- Now, my own precious, Emilie,
now that your unhappiness must have given
way to more hopeful thoughts, lets you
and mantee talk this matter over, like a
sensible man and woman ought to do- And
in the very first place, let me beseech
& implore my darling not to be so rash
as to write to the Surgeon General about
my stay in Arizona! For he would not
tell you, & besides, it might annoy him
& in order to satisfy his annoyance, he
might keep me, even beyond my time, in
Arizona- The tour is four years in this
department- I've been informed of that
fact, & that is all that I can possibly ex-
tract from any one- Any inquiries from
you or myself, could only result in dam-
-age to my prospects- I trust, loving lit-
-tle wifie, that this brief allusion to that
matter will check any intentions of yours
of writing to the Surgeon General- The thing
must not be done! Now, In the next place,
my darling wifie, you must remember that
the return of Mrs. Hentig, Mrs. Overton, &
other ladies to this Department is quite a
different thing from your return- They
are compelled to return, or else remain
absent from their husbands for the bal-
-ance of their lives. Their husbands are
stationed out in these territories all
their lives, whereas your's, after a defi-
-nite tour here, is ordered East- The
two cases are entirely dissimilar- Again,
suppose, I say you can come back to Apa-
che & just for argument's sake- We will leave
out of view the difficulty of transportation
Page 5) for the time being- It is now Decr
16th & by the time this letter reaches you, it
will be sometime in January 1880 -- very good-
Now, to bring you back to Arizona, (&
there is only one route for you to take, and
that is, by way of San Francisco and Tuson)
would cost every dollar of $400, and to raise
that amount, would require, at least Jan &
February pay- Very good, we will suppose
that on the 1st of march you should start
for Arizona, how long would it take you
to reach apache? Certainly twenty days,
my precious wifie, at the shortest reckon-
ing. Well say you would reach here March
20th. Now suppose after all that money
is spent, (and bear in mind, my darling wifie,
that husband would not begrudge the
money, even if it was $5,000!) suppose that
I should be ordered out in May, only
a month & a half after you arrive,
then, don't you perceive that we would
have made a terrible mistake! All that
trip, with its tediousness & fatigue to
you and Lawrence (& you know, you couldn't
bring a nurse with you,) would have
been so much trouble for nothing! Is
it not every word true, my darling wifie?
Even suppose that I remained six months
longer, till Octr, would that short stay
repay you, for all your trouble? And when
we went East, what would we have to
fix our home up sweetly with? I really
didn't think you wanted to spend any
more money on Arizona, my precious wife!
Where would our crockery come from,
my darling wife? Where would a cook come
from? Surely, my precious wifie hasn't so
soon forgotten how much trouble we had
with cooks, and she knows that I would be
distressed to death if she had to take upon
her darling self, the same old drudgery!
Has anything gone wrong in your rela-
tions with any of your family to cause
any unpleasantness? I certainly think not.
Surely, no one is trying to treat you slight-
-ingly, my darling! Your visit must be
pleasant to your sister Annie, aint it?
You surely haven't quarrelled? I know
that it is very foolish in me to write in
such a style, as there is not a shade of
a possibility. I know, that you are not
having the most pleasant time at your
Sister's- Certainly Lawrence's row's with
little May are not going to drive my
darling wifie back to Arizona-
Get a nice, supple quince switch (Mr. Gate-
wood, who has just entered & is lying flat
on his back on my bed, suggested the quince
switch, as he says that he knows, from ex-
perience, that there is no article superior
to the quince for tickling “kidlings”,) and “inter-
-view” his little “shanks” out in the woodshed.
But seriously, my darling wife, don't let your
life be worried by thoughts of returning
to Arizona- I know no good reason why
you should not expect me by June 30th, at
the outside- Just make up your mind
like a sensible wifie, that I am coming
home by June and fix your thoughts on
that time- It is more than likely that I
will come east then- When that time shall
have arrived, & I do not come, then & not
till then, will it be time for you to begin
to trouble your darling self about it.
Indeed, my precious wife, there is no ex-
-cuse for your borrowing trouble in
this way. It will only make your life
wretched and you are going on a false
assumption about my stay in Arizona,
Do pray, lovie, I beseech you, by all
the love you bear toward your poor
ugly old mantee, don't conjure up fright-
-ful visions of my staying forever out
here, and then frighten all the life out of
your young heart by these phantoms
of your own uneasy mind! Come, pre-
-cious wifie, that will never do! You will
only render both yourself & your mantee
miserable, & all to no purpose- It will be
better, cheaper, less troublesome, more pleas-
-ant and more sensible for my darling to
stay east, than to come to Arizona, & then
have to return in June- After you have
spent Jan & Feb. with Sister A., go to see
brother Jimmie & Sister Laurie- They would
both be more than delighted to see my
sweet wife & boy- Husband wishes to
see his darlings just as badly as they
wish to see him, but he has made up
his mind to wait patiently & trust in
the Lord -- and he knows his Emily wifie will
do the same- She is too sweet & loving &
brave to write in so melancholic a strain.
Mrs Hentig is longing to get away from
Apache, & says she would give anything to
be able to get away- The mail leaves to-
morrow morning & I have several other letters
to write -- so precious wifie must excuse this
short note- Very best love to all- Write often
and think of me always as your fond husband,
who loves you more & more every day,
div1.closer:
Walter-
P.S. Kisses
& love for
Mama &
Laurie-
W.-
P.S. Please tell
me the No. &
Street of your
new Home,
or I will write
Care Vaughan,
Barnes & Co.
W.
